1.1. The purpose of this document is to outline the first safety protocol across the Trust.

This document aims to minimise risk of fire and smoke events in Mid-Essex Hospitals Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust property and other places where Trust staff are contracted to work. As such it applies to all staff, patients and visitors and contractors.

The Trust will ensure maintenance of buildings, fire response equipment, completion and audit of associated records, identification of unwanted fire alarms and seek to identify potential hazards and reduce fire risk in respect of all buildings.

Health Technical Memorandum 05-01: Managing Healthcare Fire Safety- took effect from October 2006 and sets out the Department of Health's policy on fire safety in the NHS in England. It includes best practice guidance on management arrangements for fire safety recognising that it presents one method of managing fire safety and that there may be other ways to manage fire safety effectively. This document replaces Firecode - Policy and Principles (1994).

Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order October 2005 From October 2006, the Order replaced previous fire safety legislation in England and Wales. The Order covers ‘general fire precautions' and other fire safety duties which are needed to protect ‘relevant persons' in case of fire in and around most ‘premises'. The Order requires fire precautions to be put in place ‘where necessary' and to the extent that it is reasonable and practicable in the circumstances of the case
Means any person (including the responsible person) who may be lawfully on the premises; and any person in the immediate vicinity who is at risk from a fire on the premises.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities can been seen as outlined in the MSEPO-19007 Fire Safety Policy.
Fire Response Team
5.1.1 The Trust has set up a Fire Response Team to ensure that, in the event of fire, personnel are mobilised rapidly to assist in the fire zone.
5.1.2 The Fire Response Team consists of staff including Clinical Site Managers or Senior Duty Nurses, Security Staff, Porters, maintenance and fire officer when available.
5.1.3 Fire Response Teams are contacted by bleep, pagers or hand held radio.
5.1.4 Fire Response Team duties are explained in the relevant Trust appendix.
5.1.5 Switchboard duties are explained in the relevant Trust appendix.
Staff Support after a fire incident
5.2.1 Debriefing, staff can find it helpful if they are brought together soon after a fire incident, to discuss what happened. This process of debriefing may have two functions:
To establish the details of what happened and
To provide support.
5.2.2 People may be traumatised by being involved in a fire and it is important that any debriefing does not focus solely on how they performed, but addresses effects on them as individuals.

5.2.3 Counselling is available to staff on an individual basis via the Occupational Health Service and Associate Directors and Clinical Directors may recommend to their line managers arrangements via Occupational Health for group counselling support.
Fire Risk Assessments
5.3.1 The Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 (RRFSO) applies to all workplaces where people are employed and requires a Fire Risk Assessment to be undertaken.
5.3.2 Fire Risk Assessments are to be completed by the Trust's Fire Officer to identify those measures that need to be taken to comply with legislative requirements.

5.3.3 The risk assessments should be reviewed as a minimum on an annual basis unless incident recommendations or events demand otherwise. Our fire safety system is based upon this assessment of risk, the removal of hazards and the protection of persons from any hazards that remain. The focus of the Trust's fire safety system is to promote the avoidance of fires and to mitigate the effect of fire.

5.3.4 Once performed the fire risk assessments will be shared with the area manager for them to address any actions identified. The significant findings from the fire risk assessments are to be included on the risk assessment action plan.
5.3.5 A central record of the fire risk assessments will be held electronically by the Fire Officer.
The effectiveness both of emergency plans for dealing with a fire and of various aspects of fire training should be tested by means of practical fire drills/action plan rehearsals.
Practical fire drills should take place at least once a year and simulate conditions in which at least one of the escape routes is deemed to be obstructed by fire or smoke.
Facilities staff suitably trained and nominated by the Fire Officer can be contacted to attend, silence and reset the fire alarm where a fire drill/evacuation is planned.
During drills, the member of staff who is told of the supposed outbreak should operate the fire alarm, and thereafter the fire routine should be rehearsed as fully as circumstances allow.
The progress of drills should be monitored by specially-nominated, competent staff (Fire Officer or a member of the Fire Response Team).
Records giving details of the drills and their outcome should be kept (using the log book kept with the fire alarm panel) and the Fire Officer should hold a central record.
Drills should not endanger those taking part or patients.
All equipment testing and maintenance will be performed by competent persons / companies and conform to the relevant British Standards.
Fire Detection and Alarm Systems

7.1.1 Fire Alarm and Detection systems within the Trust premises must be installed and maintained in accordance with British Standard 5839 – part 1. This standard is a code of practice containing general recommendations covering a wide range of building types. However, it is also recommended within this strategy that more specific guidance is available within the Health Technical Memorandum 05-03: Operational provisions Part B: Fire detection and alarm Systems. This document is intended to supplement BS 5839 -1 by:
Applying the recommendations of the British Standard to healthcare premises occupied by dependent and highly dependent patients;
Amplifying and interpreting specific clauses of the standard in the light of the above;
Providing additional recommendations over and above those in BS 5839 -1, which may in some instances apply and modify that standard.
7.1.2 When the fire alarm is activated, either by automatic fire detection or by manual operation of a call point, the following events will take place simultaneously:
Alarm sounders (including flashing lights in some areas) will sound continuously (evacuation) in the affected fire zone and intermittently (alert) in adjacent zones;
Fire resisting doors on electro-magnets in and around the affected zone will close automatically;
Fire dampers will close;
Lifts will ground where programmed to do so;
The affected zone will be indicated on the relevant fire alarm panel and repeater panels.

7.1.3 At Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust the alarm panel in the switch room will sound and indicate the location of the incident. An investigation of the cause of the activation will be carried out by the fire response team before the Fire Service is called. The time allowed for this investigation is five minutes and will be monitored by the telephone room operatives. Should at any time it be confirmed that it is a smoke or fire situation this information will be transmitted immediately to the Fire Service by the telephonist making a 999 call. The
appropriate gate entry number and location will also be noted and given at this time.

7.1.4 At Mid-Essex Hospitals Trust and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust the Fire Service are called automatically on the event of a detector being activated or a call point being operated. The fire response team investigate the cause of the activation and await the arrival of the Fire Service.
Alarm Panel
7.2.1 Trust premises are covered by a comprehensive fire alarm system incorporating automatic fire and smoke detection and manual call points.
7.2.2 Fire detection and alarm systems serve to enhance safety and reduce loss by the detection of fire, and enable an alarm signal to be generated so that emergency actions may be taken.

7.2.3 The Estates and Facilities Management (EFM) nominated senior manager has engaged an external competent company to perform periodic inspection, testing and inspection of our Fire Alarm Systems; this should be carried out on an annual basis.

7.2.4 The competent company will also perform the required ‘system cause and effects' to be tested annually. This includes putting the system through an evacuation procedure and operating plant shutdown and linked systems.
7.2.5 The results of alarm testing and servicing should be recorded.
Manual call points

7.3.1  The switch mechanism of every single call point will be tested. The alarm system is tested by Facilities staff on a weekly basis by activating a different alarm call point each time in rotation. During the alarm test the opportunity should be taken to check audibility of the alarm throughout the test area and also to test the correct operation of doors which are held open on devices designed to release automatically on sounding of the alarm.
Automatic Fire Detection
7.4.1 Appropriate fire detection is installed in plant rooms, medical gas manifold rooms and ready-use medical gas cylinder stores

7.4.2 All automatic fire detection will be examined, as far as practicable, to ensure they have not been damaged, painted or otherwise adversely affected. Thereafter every detector will be appropriately and functionally tested by an external competent company
7.4.3 The results of alarm testing and servicing should be recorded.
Testing Schedule

table_items.text: The requirements for routine testing are set out within BS 5839- 1:2002 Part 6, and are summarized below. This testing can usually be carried out in-house by a person who has received basic instruction in operation of the alarm system. The control panel should be checked daily to confirm that there are no faults on the system.

Every week, at approximately the same time, a manual call point should be operated during normal working hours. The test which should last for less than one minute is used to check correct operation of the control panel and audibility within the building. The test should also be used to check that the correct operation of doors and shutters designed to close automatically on activation of the alarm. Occupants should be informed of the time of the test and asked to report any problems with receiving the signal. In premises where some employees work a different schedule of hours so that they would normally miss the test, a second test may be carried out a time when they are on duty. Where the system is connected to an alarm receiving monitoring centre, the centre should be informed of the test immediately before it takes place

Standby power supplies should be checked on a monthly basis in accordance with BS 5839-1:2002 Part 6. The result of the tests should be recorded including the identity of the call point which was tested. Testing of off-site buildings.
All devices must be tested over a 12 month period. System cause and effect to be tested annually (putting the system through an evacuation procedure and operating plant shut down and linked systems).

data.text: Portable Fire Extinguishers

7.6.1 All portable fire extinguishers comply with BS EN 3, Parts 3, 6 and 7, and BS 7863:2009 and receive periodic inspection, maintenance and testing, to original manufacturer's instructions recommendations and in accordance with the requirements of BS 5306 Part 3 2017 and amendments, by an external contractor engaged by Estates & Facilities, at least once a year. All replacement fire extinguishers will comply with and BS EN 3-7 and fire blankets to BS EN 1869.
7.6.2 Managers of areas provided with portable fire extinguishers should visibly check them for damage or tampering on a monthly basis and report any defects to facilities help desk immediately.
Fixed Suppression Systems
7.7.1 Gas Suppression
Gas suppression systems within the Trust buildings are to be tested at 6 monthly intervals and serviced annually in accordance with BS EN 15004:2008 Part 4);

data.text: 7.7.2 Smoke Control System
The EFM will organise testing quarterly and servicing annually of smoke control systems, in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, through the use of an external contractor.
7.7.2.1Records of testing and servicing are recorded and should be held centrally by the
Estates and Facilities department.
Emergency and Escape Lighting
7.8.1 In areas occupied during the hours of darkness, or where the fire escape route passes through areas that do not have natural lighting, emergency lighting is provided.
7.8.2 The Estates and Facilities Management will organise a monthly activation test and annual full discharge test, in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, of all emergency lighting.
7.8.3 If there is provided throughout the Trust FASTEL (Fully Automatic, Self-Testing, and Emergency Lighting) they do not require these tests.
7.8.4 Records of emergency and escape lighting tests and servicing are recorded and should be held centrally by the Facilities department.
7.8.5 Emergency generators will be tested monthly and serviced annually with records being held centrally by the Estates and Facilities department.
Fire Doors

7.9.1 Fire doors are designed to prevent the spread of fire and smoke for life protection purposes. They can be identified through the provision of an identification disc which clearly identifies the fire-resisting standard of the door (for example FD30, FD30S, FD60 etc.).

7.9.2 All fire doors must remain in efficient working order at all times. To this end they will be inspected, maintained, and as necessary repaired, regularly in accordance with statutory requirements.
7.9.3 All repairs will be in accordance with the relevant British Standard.
7.9.4 Records of testing and servicing are recorded and held centrally.

7.9.5 Fire doors that are held open on electrically operated door-release mechanisms conforming to BS 5839-3:1988 must be fail-safe (that is, in the event of a fault or loss of power, the release mechanism should be triggered automatically).
7.9.6 All doors fitted with magnetic or free swing automatic door releases are linked to the fire detection and alarm system.
Fire Exits

7.10.1 Many of the final exits will also be used as everyday access to buildings and consequently should be designed to permit access for people with restricted mobility. However, there may be some exits provided only for escape purposes.
7.10.2 The design of all exits recognises the need to maintain the delicate balance between the requirements of means of escape and those of security.
7.10.3 Final exit doors must open outwards and are never provided with locks requiring a key for opening.
7.10.4 Automatic final exit doors should be operable freely by hand under any condition, including power failure; otherwise, adjacent non-automatic outward-opening doors must be provided.
7.10.5 Final exit doors from patient-access areas are provided with a slope, not a step, to facilitate access and egress for people with restricted mobility
7.10.6 Fire exit doors should be designed to BS9999:2017.
Risers
7.11.1 The wet and dry risers should be visually inspected every 6 months and inspected and pressure tested annually in accordance with BS 5306 by a suitably qualified person.
Fire Hydrants

7.12.1 Each fire hydrant is clearly indicated by a plate, affixed nearby in a conspicuous position, in accordance with BS 3251. Hydrants are inspected and pressure tested annually by a suitably qualified person.
Fire Signage

7.13.1 Signs must be used, where necessary, to help people identify escape routes and find fire-fighting equipment. These signs are required under the Health and Safety (Safety Signs and Signals) Regulations 1996.

7.13.2 Further every doorway or other exit providing access to a means of escape, other than exits in ordinary use, must comply with the requirements of Building Regulations 1991, and be provided with an exit sign.
7.13.3 In areas where emergency lighting has been considered necessary for means of escape purposes this must be illuminated in the event of a failure of the normal lighting.
Portable Appliance Testing
7.14.1 Portable Appliance testing is performed annually or otherwise dependent on appliance type by an external contractor engaged by Estates and Facilities Department to comply with BS7671:2018.
7.14.2 Records of testing and servicing are recorded and held centrally by the Estates and Facilities Department.
Lightning Protection

7.15.1 The necessity of lightning protection is determined either at design stage of new builds or through the risk assessment process of existing buildings. Where installed, the complete system should be maintained in accordance with the appropriate British/European standard (BS EN 62305-3:2006) BS EN 62305- 3:2011.
Services Control and Isolation

7.16.1 Through the Fire Officer, the Estates and Facilities Department staff have well established procedures for dealing with the safe control and isolation of services such as gas, water, electricity, ventilation, piped medical gases etc., which they may need to control during a fire.
Appointment of New Servicing Organisations

7.17.1 Where new servicing organisations are appointed, for the purposes of servicing and maintenance, then British Standard 5839-1:2017 requires the incoming organisation to check the existing fire alarm system records and highlight any major areas of non-compliance, against this standard, to the Fire Officer.
Hospital Street
7.18.1 The Hospital Street provides an essential link between departments and stairways and lifts; it is the main circulation route for staff, patients and visitors.
7.18.2 A Hospital Street is a special type of compartment that connects final exits, stairway enclosures and department entrances. It has two functions from a fire safety perspective:
It will serve the fire-and-rescue service as a fire fighting bridgehead;

If the spread of fire within a department cannot be brought under control, the occupants of the department affected may be evacuated via the hospital street to parts of the hospital not affected by the fire.
7.18.3 It is critical that Hospital Street and all other circulation routes are kept clear at all times to ensure safe egress in the event of a fire event or other emergency.

data.text: The Trusts' have adopted a Smoke Free Policy for all persons including patients, visitors, all employees and contractors when on premises owned or occupied by the Trusts.

To prevent fires from starting, smoking by service users should only occur at designated outside areas (where applicable) provided with suitable receptacles for discarded smoking materials, or in areas outside Trust property boundaries.

The use of electronic cigarettes and similar is not permitted within the premises as under current MHRA guidance, there is no regulation on the manufacturer or chemical make-up within the United Kingdom or European Union.

Charging of electrical items should not be undertaken unless the charger has been portable appliance tested (PAT) and the charging unit is original equipment provided by the manufacturer. This included in Fire Safety training. Patients are to be discouraged by staff from using chargers unless portable appliance tested (PAT).
Christmas Trees

11.1.1 Only fire retardant artificial trees can be used within the buildings controlled by Mid-Essex Hospitals Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, the use of natural trees even if treated with fire retardant spray is strictly prohibited.

11.1.2 The department should perform a full risk assessment to identify an area suitable to site the Christmas tree, taking into account fire exit routes, firefighting equipment, evacuation methods to be employed and the availability of an electrical socket. The artificial tree provided should be sized according to the space available, be firmly based and stable when in place, well away from any heat or ignition sources.
Christmas Lights

11.2.1 These should conform to the current British Standards and, when purchased, should carry the British Standard Number or kite mark on the box. The relevant Facilities Department should check any such lights and connections before use. The lights should be switched off overnight and the power plug removed from the socket. Tinsel decorations are a conductor of electricity, and faulty lights can cause such decorations to become 'live'. Lights should not exceed 24 volts and should be fitted with a transformer.
Candles

11.3.1 Lighted candles should not be used in Mid-Essex Hospitals Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust premises, however, permission may be granted for their limited use in chapels after consultation with the Head of Fire Safety/or Fire Officer.
Decorations

11.4.1 Metal foil decorations are preferable to paper. All decorations should be hung above the reach of standing people and clear of light fittings and electrical wiring. Combustible decorations plastic, paper, Christmas cards etc. -should not be placed near sources of heat. Cotton wool should not be used for decorative purposes.
Gift Wrappings
11.5.1 Gift wrappings and similar combustible refuse should be removed from the building as soon as practicable.
Advice regarding specific types of events should be sought from the hospital Head of Fire Safety and/or Fire Officer.

Duration and frequency of fire training has been determined by a training needs analysis and is recorded in Training Policy. This analysis takes account of the fire risks present in the premises, the numbers of people at risk, and the responsibilities of staff in a fire emergency and will be periodically reviewed.

All staff will receive corporate induction training immediately on appointment and during local induction training which will be provided by their manager. Further face to face training may occur in clinical areas.

Following corporate induction, training must be repeated by attendance on mandatory update training as and when required. In addition, completion of eLearning training if appropriate must be repeated as and when required.
Training sessions are well publicised, and managers will ensure local arrangements are made, in good time, for the release of staff.
Corporate Induction
13.5.1 All staff will receive induction training before or immediately on appointment provided by the Fire Officer, their nominated assistant, or via e-learning.
Local Induction
13.6.1 All staff will receive local induction training in their department provided by their manager.
13.6.2 Where staff are working in areas where there are specific risks or hazards, the induction training must be supplemented by job-specific instruction as soon as their employment commences.
Face to face training

13.7.1 Staff involved with the direct care of patients, who may need to help evacuate others, may receive instruction more frequently than those who may only be required to evacuate themselves from the building on the sounding of the fire alarm. To facilitate this, additional face to face training sessions are provided by the Fire Officer or their nominated assistant.

13.7.2 Manual Handling Training provided by the Manual Handling trainers in accordance the Manual Handling Policy and Procedure and, as part of the mandatory training detailed in the Training Policy will support the fire evacuation training delivered separately with respect to appropriate manual handling techniques.
13.7.3 Awareness and a suitable level of instruction in the use of the vertical evacuation aids used within Trust buildings such as Albac Mats or SkiSheets must be provided to an appropriate level.

13.7.4 The special problems of moving patients from critical care areas, and similar locations, where highly dependent people are cared for is provided locally within the environment and should be regularly and well-rehearsed.
Statutory and mandatory annual update training
13.8.1 All staff will attend the statutory and mandatory training provided at the required frequency.

13.8.2 The training is provided by the Fire Officer or their nominated assistant, other suitable in-house staff and external consultants as appropriate. This training aims to provide an overview of basic fire safety awareness and to inform attendees of Trust fire procedure, evacuation (including of patients), evacuation teams and emergency fire-fighting equipment.
13.8.3 Theoretical training in evacuating patients is covered in the clinical training part of the manual handling training.
Specialised training

13.9.1 Specialised training, for those with specific responsibilities in the event of fire, such as, ‘Fire Response Team members', will be developed and delivered by the Fire Officer or an appointed specialist external consultant.
